Cu embedded phosphorene is evaluated as single-atom catalyst through DFT calculations for carbon monoxide oxidation reaction. Furthermore, the energy and structural behavior of this catalyst is also studied. We adopted Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism, Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism and Trimolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanism for CO oxidation by employing Cu embedded phosphorene catalyst. In the LH mechanism (CO + O2 → OOCO → CO2 + O*), the activation energy barrier for the formation of peroxy type intermediate OOCO is 15.36 kcal/mol. Furthermore, this intermediate is dissociated into CO2 and O* in the rate-limiting step with an energy barrier of 5.91 kcal/mol. In the ER mechanism (CO + O2 → CO3 → CO2 + O*), a carbonate-like intermediate is formed after the adsorption of the CO molecule over the pre-adsorbed O2 molecule. The activation energy barrier for the formation of this intermediate is 52.54 kcal/mol. This intermediate is dissociated into CO2 molecule and O* moiety in the rate-limiting step with an energy barrier of 28.46 kcal/mol. In the TER mechanism (2CO + O2→ OCO-OCO → 2CO2), an O2 molecule is activated over the pre-adsorbed two CO molecules and an intermediate OCO-OCO is formed. The activation energy for this reaction is only 2.27 kcal/mol. This intermediate is further dissociated into two CO2 molecules after the elongation of bond length of O2 from 1.41 Å to 1.57 Å with an energy barrier of 7.36 kcal/mol as a rate-limiting step. Ultimately, these two CO2 molecules are desorbed from the surface of the catalyst and -104.84 kcal/mol is released exothermically. Hence, the results manifest that Cu-embedded phosphorene is a promising and highly activated catalyst for CO oxidation by following the TER mechanism. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single atom catalysis Phosphorene CO oxidation Heterogenous catalysis DFT 1 Introduction The emission of carbon monoxide (CO) continues to spoil our environment for a few decades [1]. Spinel catalysts [2], hopcalite catalyst [3], transitions metals-based catalysts [4-6], and green catalysts [7] are the various approaches to fix carbon monoxide emission. The oxidation of CO has gained much attention due to its remarkable potential to overcome CO emission [8-12]. In the recent past, single-atom catalysis (SAC) [13-18] has revolutionized the field of CO oxidation [19-23] and hydrogen evolution reaction [24-28] to achieve the high catalytic activity, stability, and maximum utilization of metal atom embedded supports [13]. Earlier studies have proven that several noble metals Pt [29-31], Pd [32-34], Rh [35, 36], Ru [37], and Au [38] have the potential to catalyze the CO oxidation reaction efficiently. However, these metals are costly and usually catalyze the reaction at a high temperature which makes them non-feasible economically. Other transition metals such as Mn [39], Fe [40], Co [41], Ni [42], Cu [43], and Zn [44] based catalysts have also gained the attention of the researchers because these metals are cheaper and readily available with high abundance. Graphene [45, 46], MoS2 [47], and h-boronitride [48, 49] are prominent supports in the catalytic process for CO oxidation reaction. Black phosphorus is two dimensional (2D) layered material named phosphorene which is the most stable allotrope of phosphorus. It originates from white phosphorus by heating it to 200°C under high pressure of about 1.2GPa [50, 51]. Phosphorene layers can be separated through mechanical exfoliation [52] or sonication methods. These methods are similar to those used to produce graphene from graphite [53]. Phosphorene has many eminent applications such as water splitting, [54] ammonia synthesis, [55, 56] hydrogen production, [57, 58] and as an anode material in batteries. [59, 60]. It possesses an orthorhombic structure with infinite puckered layers and can sustain itself up to 400°C in the air without spontaneous combustion which manifests its stability even under harsh conditions [61, 62]. In general, various mechanisms such as Eley-Rideal (ER), Langmuir Hinshelwood (LH), and trimolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanisms have been reported for CO oxidation [22, 63]. In ER mechanism (CO + O2 → CO3 → CO2 + O*), a CO molecule is adsorbed over the preadsorbed O2 on a metal embedded support and a carbonate like intermediate is formed. This intermediate dissociates to give the final product CO2. In the LH mechanism (CO + O2 → OCOO → CO2 + O*), the co-adsorption of CO and O2 molecules occur and a peroxide type intermediate OCOO is formed which results in the desorption of the CO2 molecule as a product after the dissociation of intermediate. TER mechanism [38] (2CO + O2→ OCO-OCO → 2CO2) starts with the adsorption of O2 over two preadsorbed CO molecules forming an intermediate OCOOCO. This intermediate further dissociates and results in the desorption of two CO2 molecules as a final product. According to the literature on CO oxidation and the present study, the TER mechanism is considered more energetically favorable and gives a high reaction rate than bimolecular ER and LH mechanisms [31, 33]. The multidirectional use of phosphorene suggested us to probe its potential as a substrate towards CO oxidation reaction. Fortunately, the fabrication and characterization of the phosphorene sheet have been done experimentally which provoked us to investigate this material as a support for CO oxidation using SAC. The objective of this work is to investigate the geometry and catalytic activity of a single Cu embedded phosphorene substrate for CO oxidation using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The choice of Cu metal has been made due to various studies demonstrating Cu to be cheap, environmental-friendly, and abundant in nature [43, 64, 65]. Furthermore, its superior catalytic activity toward CO oxidation reaction [66, 67] and better binding with phosphorene sheet compared to other metals like Ag and Au [68] make it the most suitable candidate to be doped on phosphorene sheet to study the CO oxidation process. 2 Computational details All the calculations were performed using Gaussian 09 Rev. D01 [69]. The modeling and visualization of optimized molecules were performed using GaussView 5.0.9 (Gaussian Inc.). Adamo's hybrid version of Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof functional (PBE0) [70, 71] has been used for all the calculations. For all optimizations and frequency calculations, Ahlrich's triple ζ basis set def2-TZVP [72] has been used along with Grimme's empirical D3 correction with Becke-Johnston damping (D3BJ) [73-75]. PBE0/def2-TZVP is a well-known level of theory for late transition metal adsorbed 2D materials (such as graphene). Moreover, PBE0 method is also well reported method for studying CO oxidation reaction using SAC [76-81]. Frequencies were calculated on the optimized structures to confirm them as true minimum energy structures on the potential energy surface. The transition state geometries were located by using the Berny algorithm as implemented in Gaussian 09. An orthorhombic 3 × 2 sheet containing 46 phosphorus atoms was used as a phosphorene sheet. A 3 × 2 sheet arrangement in which phosphorus atoms are arranged along the arm-chair and zig-zag directions to avoid interaction between neighbouring unit cells was used as phosphorene sheet. Formation energy (E form ) for each substrate has been calculated as: E f o r m = E m / p − ( E m + E p ) Where E m/p is the electronic energy of metal anchored phosphorene support; E m is the energy of the metal atom acting as SAC; E p is the energy of pristine phosphorene support. The activation energy (E a ) is defined as: E a = E T S − E I S Activation energy is the energy difference between transition state (E TS ) and initial state (E IS ). The reaction is exothermic if E ads has a negative value while a positive value indicates an endothermic reaction. In this article the units of energy used throughout is kcal/mol. In many other articles, other units like kJ/mol and eV have been used. The following conversion formula can be beneficial to compare different units in the literature. 1 k c a l / m o l = 4.2 k J / m o l = 0.043 e V Charge analysis has been done using the same level of theory with Hirshfeld charge analysis. A comparison of NBO and Hirshfeld showed generally similar trends except that the amount of charge on copper is slightly changed. The values of charges from NBO analysis are also given in Fig. S2 in the supporting information. 3 Results and discussion Owing to the zigzag structure of the phosphorene sheet, the adsorption of the Cu atom on the phosphorene sheet has been studied by placing it at different sites on the phosphorene sheet used for calculations. The choice of isolated Cu metal atom on the surface of the substrate is due to its unique characteristics such as being cheaper, non-toxic, and rich in the earth. The optimized geometries are shown in Fig. 2. During adsorption, the Cu metal prefers to sit on top of the cavity between adjacent phosphorus atoms in the phosphorene sheet. Cu atom protrudes out of the cavity due to its larger atomic radius. The average Cu-P distance between Cu and three phosphorus atoms is 2.32 Å which is larger than a normal covalent bond length of 2.22 Å between Cu and P. While Cu is bonded at the middle and terminal sites of the phosphorene sheet (Fig. 2b and 2c), a distortion takes place in the sheet due to the larger size of Cu atom. The formation energies (E form ) for (a) adsorption, bonding at (b) middle, and (c) terminal of phosphorene support are -43.67 kcal/mol, 82.99 kcal/mol, and 80.67 kcal/mol, respectively. The positive values of the interaction energies show that the formation of these structures is not energetically feasible, and the structures would not be stable. Therefore, it is suggested that the adsorption of Cu metal on the phosphorene support is thermodynamically favorable. Moreover, frequencies of the Cu@Phosphorene vary from 83.87 to 239.19 cm−1, which illustrate good chemical stability for these metal adsorbed systems [82]. According to Hirshfeld charge analysis, the Cu metal is positively charged (0.692e) which shows its electron-donating behaviour. 3.1 Electron density differences (EDD) and natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses Electron density differences and natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses were performed through Multiwfn and Gaussian program packages to study the charge transfer between phosphorene and adsorbent atom (Cu). Cu@phosphorene topology obtained through electron density differences comprises of green and dark purple isosurfaces. Green isosurface represents depletion of electronic charge whereas, dark purple color shows an accumulation of electronic charge. Fig. 3 of the Cu@phosphorene complex shows that Cu-atom contains green and dark purple isosurfaces that demonstrate its σ-donation and back charge donation from phosphorene. Moreover, the direction of net charge donation is calculated through NBO analysis. The adsorption of Cu on phosphorene surface resulted in a 0.69e charge on Cu. This positive sign of charge (0.69e) on the Cu atom after getting positioned over phosphorene indicates the electropositive behavior of Cu and electron recipient nature of phosphorene in stable geometry of Cu@phosphorene complex. 3.2 Quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) analysis The nature of the interaction between Cu and phosphorene was confirmed through Bader's quantum theory of atoms in molecules. The various parameters used to explain the nature of bond critical points (BCPs) are electron density (ρ), Laplacian of electron density ( ∇ 2 ρ ), Lagrangian kinetic energy (G(r), potential energy (V(r)), total energy density (H(r)) and individual bond interaction energy (Eint). BCPs values obtained through QTAIM analysis are given in Table 2. and the topology of the complex is given in Fig. 4. The number of BCPs between Cu and phosphorene surface are three. Values of all parameters related to these BCPs are in the range of partial covalent interaction which indicates the stability of the Cu atom on the phosphorene surface. Among these BCPs, the strongest interaction is observed between Cu4 and P2 of phosphorene. 3.3 Adsorption of O, O2, CO, CO2, and co-adsorption of 2CO molecules on Cu@Phosphorene Before discussing the reaction mechanism for CO oxidation, a discussion on the adsorption potential of different possible species at Cu@phosphorene would be of great interest. DFT calculations [35, 83] were performed on different adsorption species i.e. O, O2, CO, CO2, and co-adsorption of 2CO molecules to investigate their adsorption behavior towards Cu-metal adsorbed on the phosphorene support. The most suitable and stable configurations of these adsorbent species have been discussed with their adsorption energies and bond lengths. Keeping in view the results, a CO molecule was adsorbed perpendicularly on the Cu@phosphorene support with a calculated adsorption energy of -61.39 kcal/mol (Fig. 5). The C—O bond length in CO was decreased from 1.16 Å to 1.13 Å. A vertically adsorbed O2 molecule prefers to lie parallel to the Cu@phosphorene catalyst. The O—O bond length increased from 1.26 Å to 1.31 Å and two Cu—O bonds were formed. The adsorption energy of the O2 molecule was calculated as -62.32 kcal/mol that lie very close to that of the CO molecule (-61.39 kcal/mol) which suggested their similar adsorption behavior towards CO oxidation reaction. These results indicated that adsorption of O2 happens before the catalytic process and also helps in avoiding CO poisoning at the active site of the substrate. It is worthy to note that there should be a moderate difference in adsorption energies and the reaction barrier of adsorbates. It is suggested that the smaller adsorption energy difference among these species undergo less repulsion which would facilitate the CO oxidation reaction. The desired product of this attempt is CO2 which is desorbed over the metal catalyst and manifests a weak interaction with the smallest adsorption energy of -41.28 kcal/mol. The smallest adsorption energy for the CO2 molecule indicates that this would be easily desorbed from the surface of the catalyst upon formation. The atomic O is adsorbed at the top of the substrate to form Cu-O having a bond length of 1.78 Å. The calculated adsorption energy for atomic O is -138.45 kcal/mol which indicates its strong binding with the metal catalyst. The highest adsorption energy of atomic O suggested the ease of formation of peroxo-type intermediate in LH mechanism but the overall energy barriers for LH mechanism are relatively higher and therefore is not considered for CO oxidation process. The co-adsorption of two CO molecules possesses calculated adsorption energy of -72.66 kcal/mol which indicates that the Tri-molecular Eley-Rideal mechanism is favorable for CO oxidation. The adsorption energies of O, O2, CO, CO2, co-adsorption of 2CO molecules suggested a competition between adsorption of O2 and CO molecules on the Cu embedded phosphorene catalyst for CO oxidation reaction. 3.4 Reaction mechanisms for CO oxidation For a better understanding of CO oxidation reaction, all the proposed reaction mechanisms such as Eley-Rideal (ER), Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH), and Trimolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanisms have been studied. 3.4.1 Trimolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) Mechanism Firstly, an adsorbent, containing two CO molecules coadsorbed over the Cu embedded phosphorene, is modeled and optimized. Then, an O2 molecule is physisorbed over that adsorbent in the initial state (IS). This adsorbed O2 molecule is activated and stretched from 1.19 Å to 1.27 Å in the transition state (TS-1). The O2 molecule gets further stretched from 1.27 Å to 1.41 Å thus forming interactions with the carbon atoms of preadsorbed CO molecules on the metal and an intermediate (IM) OCO–OCO is formed with the release of 13.06 kcal/mol energy. The activation energy for the formation of IM is 2.27 kcal/mol which is lower than that of Cu-embedded nitrogen-doped graphene [63] (2.77 kcal/mol), Ni-embedded h-boron nitride nanosheet [84] (10.84 kcal/mol), and Co embedded divacancy graphene [85] (28.83 kcal/mol). The intermediate (IM) OCO–OCO bridge then gets dissociated into two CO2 molecules after the two oxygen atoms of O2 binding to CO and separating apart from each other from 1.41 Å to 1.59 Å in the TS-2 (Fig. 6). The bond distances between the Carbon of the CO molecule and the activated oxygen shrink from 1.37 Å to 1.30 Å in the TS2. Subsequently, two CO2 molecules are formed (FS) where the bond angles of the formed CO2 molecule change to make it linear, and the bond length of the C-O bond reduces from 1.30 Å to 1.16 Å. and are easily desorbed from the substrate due to weak interaction energy as shown in the previous section. The two CO2 molecules are desorbed from the Cu@phosphorene exothermically in the final state (FS) and 112.20 kcal/mol energy is released. The reaction barriers of OCO–OCO formation and dissociation into CO2 molecules are 2.27 kcal/mol and 7.36 kcal/mol, respectively. Both the transition states (TS-1) and (TS-2) have been identified by finding a single imaginary frequency. The average desorption energy for the CO2 molecule is -11.33 kcal/mol. 3.4.1.1 Charge Transfer Analysis of TER Mechanism NBO charge analysis of Cu doped phosphorene reveals that Cu acts as a donor (with 0.692e charge), while the same charge is received by the phosphorene surface (Fig. S1). In the IS, the charge on Cu is -0.183e which is well in line with the charge transferred from two CO ligands to the metal atom. In TS1, IM, and TS2, as highly electronegative oxygen atoms approached closer with carbons atoms of CO which are coordinated with Cu@phosphorene, the intensity of the negative sign begins to reduce on the Cu atom as it goes from -0.183e in the IS to -0.158e in TS1 and -0.044 in TS2. The decrease in negative charge on the Cu surface, reveals the bond formation between oxygen and Carbon atoms of CO. The positive sign of NBO charges on Cu (0.368) in the last step (FS) clearly indicates that CO ligands have left the catalyst surface in form of CO2. 3.4.2 Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) Mechanism In the LH mechanism, the co-adsorption of O2 and CO molecules occurs over the Cu@phosphorene support which is used as the initial state (LH-IS1) configuration. The adsorbed O2 molecule is stretched from 1.29 Å in LH-IS1 to 1.38 Å in LH-TS1. This O2 molecule approaches the Cu@phophorene in the transition state (LH-TS1) with a relatively large energy barrier (15.36 kcal/mol) and converted into peroxy type OOCO intermediate in the intermediate state (LH-IM) with the release of energy of 4.91 kcal/mol energy. The formation of this intermediate (LH-IM) seems a little difficult due to the relatively higher energy barrier of 15.36 kcal/mol. In the LH-IM state, the O2 molecule is elongated from 1.29 Å (in LH-IS) to 1.45 Å. Also, the bond distance between the activated oxygen and the carbon of the CO molecule decreases from 1.28 Å in LH-IM to 1.23 Å in LH-TS2. This intermediate configuration proceeds to the final state (LH-FS1) after the dissociation of OOCO into an O* moiety and CO2 molecule in the LH-TS2 with an energy barrier of 5.91 kcal/mol. Additionally, the O*–CO2 bond distance is elongated from 1.45 Å in (LH-IM) to 1.67 Å in (LH-TS2). The CO2 molecule is released from the surface of the substrate in the final state (LH-FS1) with the release of 60.24 kcal/mol energy (Fig. 7). Bond lengths of the C–O bonds reduce from 1.23 Å and 1.20 Å in LH-TS2 to 1.16 Å in LH-FS1, and a linear CO2 molecule is formed in the final state. The remaining O* moiety left over the Cu@phosphorene catalyst can be removed by the attack of another CO molecule. In the initial state LH-IS2, an incoming CO molecule is at a distance of 2.53 Å from the O* moiety. This reaction (O* + CO → CO2) occurs in the formation of a CO2 molecule. The bond length of an O* moiety and a CO molecule is reduced from 2.23 Å in (LH-TS3) to 1.17 Å in the final state (LH-FS2) which means that bonding interactions between an O* moiety and a CO molecule have been initiated, with a significant weakening of a bond connecting an O* moiety with a Cu metal catalyst. The activation energy barrier for the formation of another CO2 molecule is only 0.94 kcal/mol in LH-TS3 which is released from the surface of the catalyst exothermically with the release of 71.67 kcal/mol energy in the final state LH-FS2 (Fig. 8). The release of a large amount of energy manifests its easy elimination from the surface of the catalyst. 3.4.3 Eley-Rideal (ER) Mechanism In ER mechanism, the reaction starts with the adsorption of an O2 molecule over the surface of the catalyst. A CO molecule approaches the O2 species in the initial state ER-IS. With the elongation of the bond distance of the O2 molecule, the CO molecule, along with an increase in its bond length from 1.12 Å to 1.17 Å in the transition state (ER-TS1), approaches the O2 species and inserts itself into the elongated O2 and a carbonate-like (CO3) intermediate is formed. The activation energy barrier for the formation of this intermediate is much higher at 52.54 kcal/mol in the transition state (ER-TS1). The formation of carbonate type intermediate (ER-IM) is largely exothermic with the release of 167.53 kcal/mol energy. In the next step, the intermediate is dissociated into a CO2 molecule and an O* moiety with an energy barrier of 28.46 kcal/mol in the second transition state (ER-TS2). The CO2 molecule is physisorbed on the surface and a small amount of energy is released in the final state (ER-FS, Fig. 9). The bond angles of the formed CO2 molecule change accordingly to make it linear and the bond lengths of the C-O bonds reduces from 1.17 Å and 1.18 Å in (ER-TS2) to 1.16 Å in (ER-FS). Eventually, The ER mechanism for CO oxidation reaction is not favorable due to higher activation energy barriers. Table 4 shows a comparison of rate-limiting step and energy released for CO oxidation by employing various catalysts using the TER mechanism (compared with the literature values), LH, and ER mechanisms. These results demonstrate that Cu embedded phosphorene has great potential for CO oxidation due to high stability and favorable energetics and follows the TER mechanism. 4 Conclusion Using the density functional theory calculations, the catalytic activity of Cu embedded phosphorene (Cu@phosphorene) catalyst has been studied towards CO oxidation reaction. Various configurations of this catalyst are investigated to choose the appropriate configuration having the lowest energy. Among all the mechanisms, the TER mechanism is the most suitable and energetically favorable for CO oxidation using Cu@phosphorene catalyst because the activation energy barriers of LH and ER mechanisms are 15.36 kcal/mol and 52.54 kcal/mol, respectively. Furthermore, the rate-limiting step of LH and ER mechanisms are 5.91 kcal/mol and 28.46 kcal/mol, respectively which makes them unfavorable for the CO oxidation process. This catalyst is highly favorable by adopting the TER mechanism where a large amount of energy (104.84 kcal/mol) is released. The results of this struggle can be valuable for the preparation of an active, energetically favorable, economic, and stable catalyst for CO oxidation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Cu embedded phosphorene is evaluated as single-atom catalyst through DFT calculations for carbon monoxide oxidation reaction. Furthermore, the energy and structural behavior of this catalyst is also studied. We adopted Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism, Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism and Trimolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanism for CO oxidation by employing Cu embedded phosphorene catalyst. In the LH mechanism (CO + O2 → OOCO → CO2 + O*), the activation energy barrier for the formation of peroxy type intermediate OOCO is 15.36 kcal/mol. Furthermore, this intermediate is dissociated into CO2 and O* in the rate-limiting step with an energy barrier of 5.91 kcal/mol. In the ER mechanism (CO + O2 → CO3 → CO2 + O*), a carbonate-like intermediate is formed after the adsorption of the CO molecule over the pre-adsorbed O2 molecule. The activation energy barrier for the formation of this intermediate is 52.54 kcal/mol. This intermediate is dissociated into CO2 molecule and O* moiety in the rate-limiting step with an energy barrier of 28.46 kcal/mol. In the TER mechanism (2CO + O2→ OCO-OCO → 2CO2), an O2 molecule is activated over the pre-adsorbed two CO molecules and an intermediate OCO-OCO is formed. The activation energy for this reaction is only 2.27 kcal/mol. This intermediate is further dissociated into two CO2 molecules after the elongation of bond length of O2 from 1.41 Å to 1.57 Å with an energy barrier of 7.36 kcal/mol as a rate-limiting step. Ultimately, these two CO2 molecules are desorbed from the surface of the catalyst and -104.84 kcal/mol is released exothermically. Hence, the results manifest that Cu-embedded phosphorene is a promising and highly activated catalyst for CO oxidation by following the TER mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Cu-doped phosphorene as highly efficient single atom catalyst for CO oxidation: A DFT study
